info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued March 23 at 10:53PM EDT until March 24 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Northwestern Burke County in western North Carolina... Northwestern Caldwell County in western North Carolina... * Until 200 AM EDT. * At 1053 PM EDT, Heavy rainfall has ended across northwest Caldwell and northwest Burke counties. However, excessive runoff continues over the warned area following storm-total rainfall of 2-4 inches, with 1-1.5 inches falling between 7pm and 830pm on top of saturated soils. As a result, larger streams including Wilson Creek, Warrior Fork, Roses Creek, Linville River, and Johns River are still rising rapidly. Expect these streams to continue to rise sharply for at least the next 1-3 hours, with rises continuing on Johns River, downstream of Collettsville, into the overnight hours. Therefore, because streams are continuing to rise rapidly, and out-of-bank conditions are likely to continue and/or develop over the next few hours, the Flash Flood Warning will be extended until 2am to allow excessive runoff to abate and the rate of rise on area streams to decelerate. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms. SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, low-water crossings, campgrounds, secondary roads adjacent to streams as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. Expect nuisance to Minor flooding to develop in common, flood-prone areas adjacent to the Johns River near Collettsville, as well as campgrounds and other low-lying areas near Nebo, Table Rock, and along Wilson Creek near Edgemont. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Table Rock, Lake James, Edgemont, Collettsville, Globe and Upton. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR AND GAUGE INDICATED
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
